questions.question_text: Will Canada hold a federal election before June 15, 2025?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if a federal election in Canada is officially announced and the voting day occurs at any point between March 19, 2025, and June 15, 2025. It will resolve as **No** if no such election is announced or the voting day does not occur during this period.
questions.fine_print:
- The question resolves based on the actual voting date, not just the announcement date.
- If an election is announced within the timeframe but scheduled to occur after June 15, 2025, the question resolves as **No**.
- The election must be for the federal government of Canada, not provincial or territorial elections.
questions.background_information: According to Canadian law, the next federal election must be held no later than October 20, 2025 [1](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=While%20Canadian%20law%20requires%20the,be%20chosen%20by%20Sept.%2027.)[6](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=Poilievre%E2%80%99s%20party%20is%20expected%20to,be%20decided%20by%20May%2017.). However, there are indications that opposition parties could force an earlier election, potentially by the spring of 2025 [1](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=While%20Canadian%20law%20requires%20the,be%20chosen%20by%20Sept.%2027.). Current polling suggests Pierre Poilievre's Conservative Party is favored to win a majority government with projections showing 225 seats, while Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's Liberal Party is expected to win only 46 seats [6](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=Poilievre%E2%80%99s%20party%20is%20expected%20to,be%20decided%20by%20May%2017.). The timing of the election will depend on political dynamics and strategic considerations by the current government and opposition parties.

# SUMMARY
*Question*: Will Canada hold a federal election before June 15, 2025?
*Final Prediction*: 30.0%
*Total Cost*: $0.06
*Time Spent*: 0.33 minutes


## Report 1 Summary
### Forecasts
*Forecaster 1*: 45.0%
*Forecaster 2*: 30.0%
*Forecaster 3*: 30.0%
*Forecaster 4*: 30.0%
*Forecaster 5*: 60.0%


### Research Summary
The research indicates that there is significant speculation regarding the timing of the next federal election in Canada, which is legally required to occur by October 20, 2025. Recent developments, including the leadership change from Justin Trudeau to Mark Carney in the Liberal Party, have led to discussions of a potential early election. Opposition parties are preparing for a possible snap election, particularly if a motion of no confidence is tabled after Parliament reconvenes on March 24, 2025. The Conservative Party currently holds a strong position in polls, and the Liberal Party's slow candidate nomination process has raised concerns about their readiness for an election.

Mark Carney has suggested that the next election may not occur until fall 2025, despite the possibility of an earlier election being triggered by political maneuvers or public sentiment. The Liberal Party's candidate nominations lag behind those of the Conservatives and other parties, which could impact their electoral strategy. Analysts note that if Carney's popularity rises, it may influence more Liberal MPs to participate in the election. Overall, the political landscape is dynamic, with various factors at play that could influence the timing of the next federal election in Canada. 

Sources:
- [CFJC Today Kamloops](https://cfjctoday.com/2025/03/18/opposition-parties-gearing-up-for-federal-election-in-anticipation-of-potential-writ-drop-this-weekend/)
- [The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/b5/25/3/18/n14461533.htm)
- [LifeSiteNews](https://www.lifesitenews.com/news/canadas-new-pm-mark-carney-hints-next-federal-election-wont-be-until-fall/)
- [rmoutlook.com](https://www.rmoutlook.com/opinion/editorial-federal-liberal-leadership-race-could-be-final-card-before-early-election-10360784)
- [CNET](https://www.cnet.com/news/politics/when-is-the-election-in-canada/)
- [TVA Nouvelles](https://www.tvanouvelles.ca/2025/03/12/elections-federales-canadiennes-date-et-comment-voter)
- [Toronto.com](https://www.toronto.com/news/canadians-want-to-know-when-an-election-will-be-called-heres-what-we-know/article_c1040570-58a2-5330-9071-a11372207835.html)


# RESEARCH
## Report 1 Research
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Opposition parties gearing up for federal election in anticipation of potential writ drop this weekend**
The next federal election in Canada must be held by October 20, 2025. Polls suggest the Conservatives are in a strong position to form government, ending 10 years of Liberal rule. However, the recent leadership change from Justin Trudeau to Mark Carney has given the Liberals a boost, with speculation about a snap election. Kamloops-Thompson-Cariboo MP Frank Caputo expects no trip to Ottawa, but is unsure if an election will be called before parliament returns. Caputo said, 'I'm expecting no stay in Ottawa. I don't think I will be getting on a plane to be candid. But I have been wrong every other time before.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 11:21 PM
Source:[CFJC Today Kamloops](https://cfjctoday.com/2025/03/18/opposition-parties-gearing-up-for-federal-election-in-anticipation-of-potential-writ-drop-this-weekend/)

**Canadian Federal Election May Be Held Early as Liberal Party Lags Behind in Candidate Nominations**
The Canadian federal election may be held earlier than expected, but no party has yet nominated candidates in all 343 electoral districts. The Conservative Party has nominated candidates in 258 districts, the New Democratic Party in 217, and the Quebec separatist party in 53 of the 78 districts in Quebec. In contrast, the Liberal Party has only nominated candidates in about half of the districts. According to CBC, Christine de Clercy, a professor of politics at Trent University, attributes the Liberal Party's slow nomination process to the dissatisfaction of many MPs with Prime Minister Trudeau and their decision not to run in the next election. She notes that if Mark Carney becomes the leader of the Liberal Party and his popularity increases rapidly, it may encourage some MPs to change their minds. For example, Industry Minister Anita Anand and MP Wayne Long have switched from not running to running. De Clercy is unsure whether the presence of incumbent MPs will make it harder to recruit new candidates and notes that the background checks may be too short, which could lead to risks such as the exposure of controversial social media posts from a candidate's youth. Although Parliament will not reconvene until March 24, Carney has not yet taken his seat in Parliament and has hinted that he may call an early election. Several senior elected officials believe that Canada needs a government with strong public support to deal with the economic pressure from US tariffs. Anand said on CBC's Power and Politics program on Monday, 'The Prime Minister is committed to the election process, and we very much hope he will continue as Prime Minister with us.' Meanwhile, the opposition parties have already announced that they will table a motion of no confidence in the Liberal government after Parliament reconvenes, which would trigger an early election.
Original language: zh
Publish date: March 18, 2025 08:37 PM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/b5/25/3/18/n14461533.htm)

**Canadian Federal Election May Be Held Early as Liberal Party Lags Behind in Candidate Nominations**
The Canadian federal election may be held earlier than expected, but no party has completed candidate nominations in all 343 electoral districts. The Conservative Party has nominated candidates in 258 districts, the New Democratic Party in 217, and the Quebec Bloc in 53 of the 78 districts in Quebec. In contrast, the Liberal Party has only nominated candidates in about half of the districts. According to CBC, Professor Cristine de Clercy of Trent University attributes the slow pace of Liberal Party nominations to the dissatisfaction of several MPs with Prime Minister Trudeau and their decision not to run in the next election. She believes that if Mark Carney becomes the leader of the Liberal Party and his popularity rises quickly, some MPs may change their minds. For example, Industry Minister Anita Anand and MP Wayne Long have switched from not running to running. De Clercy notes that uncertainty about whether incumbent MPs will run can make it harder to recruit candidates, and that the short background check period may pose risks, such as the exposure of controversial social media posts from a candidate's youth. Although Parliament will not reconvene until March 24, Carney has not yet held a seat in Parliament and has hinted that he may call an early election. Several senior elected officials believe that Canada needs a government with strong public support to face the economic pressure from US tariffs. Anand said on CBC's 'Power and Politics' on Monday, 'The Prime Minister is committed to the election process, and we very much hope he will be our Prime Minister.' Meanwhile, the opposition parties have made it clear that they will table a motion of no confidence in the Liberal government after Parliament reconvenes, paving the way for an early election.
Original language: zh
Publish date: March 18, 2025 08:37 PM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/3/18/n14461533.htm)

**Canada's new PM Mark Carney hints next federal election won't be until fall - LifeSite**
Canada's new Prime Minister Mark Carney has hinted that the next federal election will not be held until autumn, saying Canadians can expect to go to the polls 'before November.' This is despite the fact that, by law, there must be a federal election within five years of the last one, which is currently scheduled for October 20, 2025. Carney's decision to postpone the election is seen as a strategic move, as the Conservative Party is currently ahead of the Liberals in the polls, although the gap has been closing since Carney's leadership win.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 17, 2025 03:01 PM
Source:[LifeSiteNews](https://www.lifesitenews.com/news/canadas-new-pm-mark-carney-hints-next-federal-election-wont-be-until-fall/)

**EDITORIAL: Federal Liberal leadership race could be final card before early election**
The selection of Mark Carney as the new Liberal leader and Prime Minister-designate has sparked speculation about an early federal election in Canada. With the deteriorating Canadian-U.S. relationship and the ongoing tariff trade war, many Canadians believe an election is necessary to give the federal government a new mandate to address these concerns. According to an Ipsos poll, 86% of Canadians agree that an election is needed, and a recent Nanos poll showed the Conservatives holding a one-point lead over the Liberals. With Carney's landslide victory, some experts predict that an early election will be called soon after he takes office. The new Yellowhead federal riding, which includes Banff and Canmore, will also be a key battleground in the upcoming election. The riding's centre-left leaning politics may give the Liberals an advantage, but the high cost of living and housing in the valley, exacerbated by U.S. tariffs, could impact local businesses and tourism. As the clock ticks on, Canadians await the next federal election, which is expected to happen before October.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 17, 2025 02:30 PM
Source:[rmoutlook.com](https://www.rmoutlook.com/opinion/editorial-federal-liberal-leadership-race-could-be-final-card-before-early-election-10360784)

**When Is the Election in Canada?**
Canada will hold federal elections this year, which will have significant implications for its trade conflict with the US. The elections have caught the attention of people outside of Canada, especially Americans. Justin Trudeau announced in January that he would step down as Canadian prime minister and leader of the Liberal Party, but his opposition to President Donald Trump's tariffs and his proposal for Canada to become the 51st state have rebuilt voter support for the Liberals. The elections will see members of Parliament elected to the country's House of Commons, with a party needing to win 172 seats to achieve a majority. The Liberal Party, led by Mark Carney, is currently ahead of the Conservative Party, led by Pierre Poilievre, in polls. However, the elections can be called earlier by order of the prime minister, and Carney is expected to call an election 'soon.' The country's electoral laws require that the elections be held no later than October 20, 2025, but it is unlikely that they will take that long.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 14, 2025 09:50 PM
Source:[CNET](https://www.cnet.com/news/politics/when-is-the-election-in-canada/)

**Early Canadian Federal Election Possible as Mark Carney Takes Liberal Party Helm**
The selection of Mark Carney as the leader of the Liberal Party could lead to an early election in Canada, potentially as early as the end of April 2025. According to Elections Canada, the election period can last between 36 and 50 days, meaning that Canadians could be called to vote as early as April 29, 2025, or as late as October 20, 2025. Justin Trudeau had suspended parliamentary work until March 24, which means that an election could be triggered from that date. 'We will make sure that Canadians have a say in the next government,' said Justin Trudeau. 'It's a great opportunity for Canadians to have a say in the direction of the country,' added Élections Canada. Canadians can vote in several ways: in person at a polling station, by mail, at an Elections Canada office, or on campus. 'If you're registered to vote on Elections Canada's website, you should receive a voter information card in the mail that will tell you the polling station hours nearest to you,' said Élections Canada. 'You can vote in person on election day or by advance voting on the 10th, 9th, 8th, and 7th days before election day.'
Original language: fr
Publish date: March 12, 2025 10:45 AM
Source:[TVA Nouvelles](https://www.tvanouvelles.ca/2025/03/12/elections-federales-canadiennes-date-et-comment-voter)

**Early Federal Election Possible in Canada: What You Need to Know**
The selection of Mark Carney as the leader of the Liberal Party could lead to an early federal election in Canada, potentially as early as the end of April 2025. According to Elections Canada, the election period can last between 36 and 50 days, meaning that Canadians could be voting as early as April 29, 2025. There are several ways to vote, including in-person, by mail, or by advance voting. Canadians can check their voter information card to find their nearest polling station and voting hours. They can also request a special ballot by mail or in person, which can be completed and returned by mail. Students and staff can also vote on campus at one of the 120 designated locations across the country. 'It's essential to be informed and prepared for the upcoming election,' said Elections Canada. 'Make sure to check your voter information card and plan your voting strategy accordingly.'
Original language: fr
Publish date: March 12, 2025 10:27 AM
Source:[Le Journal de Montreal](https://www.journaldemontreal.com/2025/03/12/elections-federales-canadiennes-date-et-comment-voter)

**Canadians want to know when an election will be called. Here's what we know**
With the Liberal party selecting Mark Carney as their new leader, Parliament remains on pause until March 24. Justin Trudeau remains prime minister until Carney is sworn in. Many Canadians are wondering when the next election will be called. According to Elections Canada, a writ is a formal written order instructing the returning officer in each electoral district to hold an election. 'Polling day must be no earlier than the 36th day and no later than the 50th day after the day on which the writ was issued,' Elections Canada said. This would mean an election sometime at the end of April or in May. A snap election could be called in two ways: once Parliament resumes on March 24, a non-confidence motion could be put on the floor, or if Carney asks Gov. General Mary Simon for the dissolution of Parliament in order to hold an election. Currently, Canada's official federal election date is set for Oct. 20, 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 04:52 PM
Source:[Toronto.com](https://www.toronto.com/news/canadians-want-to-know-when-an-election-will-be-called-heres-what-we-know/article_c1040570-58a2-5330-9071-a11372207835.html)

**Ontario election 2025: And so it begins ...**
Ontario's election campaign has begun, with Premier Ford calling for an early election. Ford will face challenges from NDP leader Marit Stiles, Liberal leader Bonnie Crombie, and Green Party leader Mike Schreiner. The election was initially set for June 2026, but Ford cited the need for a new mandate to deal with a potential Donald Trump presidency in the United States. Ford's campaign is centered around fighting U.S. tariffs, with him positioning himself as Canada's defender against these tariffs. As Ford said, 'Canada's defender against U.S. tariffs' is a central theme of his strategy to win votes.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 03:31 PM
Source:[recorder.ca](https://www.recorder.ca/news/ontario-election-2025-and-so-it-begins)

**Ontario Election 2025**
The next Ontario general election will be held on Thursday, June 2, 2022. The campaign officially began on May 3, when Premier Doug Ford asked Lieutenant Governor Elizabeth Dowdeswell to dissolve the legislature. The leaders of the four major parties, PCs, NDP, Liberals, and Greens, have released their platform pledges on health care, the economy, transportation, the environment, education, housing, and senior care. The first debate of the 2022 Ontario election was held in North Bay on May 10, and a second debate was held on May 16. Anyone who is 18 years or older, a Canadian citizen, and a resident of Ontario is eligible to vote. Ontarians can vote in person on election day, at advance polling locations, or by mail-in ballot. Voters can register to vote online through Elections Ontario's eRegistration system.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 12:30 PM
Source:[The Globe and Mail](https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/ontario-election/)

**Ontarians will be going to the polls about 15 months earlier than expected.**
Ontario Premier Doug Ford has called for an early general election, which will take place on February 27, 2025, about 15 months ahead of the scheduled election date of June 4, 2026. Ford made the announcement in response to U.S. President Donald Trump's threatened 25% tariff on Canada, which he claims would put over 500,000 jobs in Ontario's auto industry at risk. The Progressive Conservatives, led by Ford, currently hold a majority government and 79 of the 124 seats in Queen's Park. According to Ford, 'Ontario's auto industry would be dramatically impacted, with over 500,000 jobs in jeopardy, if Trump follows through with his tariff plan.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 28, 2025 07:36 PM
Source:[thesarniajournal.ca](https://www.thesarniajournal.ca/news/ontarians-will-be-going-to-the-polls-about-15-months-earlier-than-expected-10143959)

**Ontario to Hold Early Elections, Quebec Defends Secularism Law**
Ontario Premier Doug Ford has announced that the province will hold early elections in February, nearly 18 months before the scheduled date of June 2026. Ford's Progressive Conservative Party already holds a majority with 79 out of 124 seats in the Ontario Legislative Assembly. Ford aims to secure a mandate to deal with potential tariffs imposed by Donald Trump and 'attacks on families, businesses, and our communities.' Meanwhile, Quebec Premier François Legault has stated that he will respect the scheduled date of October 5, 2026, for the next general elections. Legault has also suggested boycotting American products and surtaxing maple syrup sent to the US in response to potential tariffs. The Quebec government has promised to 'fight to the end' to defend its jurisdiction and the use of the Quebec's sovereignty clause. The Supreme Court of Canada has agreed to hear a challenge to Quebec's secularism law, which prohibits public employees from wearing religious symbols. The law was adopted in 2019 and has been contested by various groups, including the National Council of Canadian Muslims, the English-Montreal school board, and the Canadian Civil Liberties Association. Additionally, Quebec City Mayor Bruno Marchand has responded to Elon Musk's alleged Nazi salute by making a peace sign and saying 'We must oppose hate with the best of ourselves.' The tramway project in Quebec has also been a point of contention between Ottawa and Quebec, with the federal government refusing to commit to funding 40% of the estimated $7.6 billion cost. Haroun Bouazzi, a Quebec solidaire member, has returned to the provincial parliament after a two-month absence, following controversy over his claims of witnessing racism in the National Assembly.
Original language: fr
Publish date: January 25, 2025 09:00 AM
Source:[lequotidien.com](https://www.lequotidien.com/actualites/politique/2025/01/25/la-semaine-politique-des-oranges-dans-le-sirop-GPRVE24QOJCYVGKM6LOBKHZU5A/)

**Premier of Canada's most populous province seeks early election because of Trump tariffs threat**
Ontario Premier Doug Ford announced plans to call an early election, citing the need for a strong mandate to fight against tariffs threatened by U.S. President Donald Trump. Ford stated, 'The attack is coming against our families, our businesses, our communities, and with a strong mandate, we will be able to fight with Donald Trump.' The election, previously scheduled for June 2026, is now set to take place on February 27, 2025. Ontario, home to 40% of Canada's population, would be severely impacted by Trump's threatened 25% tariff on Canadian imports. Ford has been actively campaigning against the tariffs, appearing on U.S. television shows and considering measures such as cutting off power supplies to the U.S. and banning U.S. alcohol products.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2025 04:14 PM
Source:[The Straits Times](https://www.straitstimes.com/world/premier-of-canadas-most-populous-province-seeks-early-election-because-of-trump-tariffs-threat)




# FORECASTS

## R1: Forecaster 1 Reasoning
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known is approximately 2 years and 3 months, as the question will resolve on June 15, 2025.

(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed is that the election would be held on or after October 20, 2025, as per Canadian law, resulting in a "No" outcome.

(c) A scenario that results in a No outcome is if the Liberal Party, under the new leadership of Mark Carney, manages to stabilize its position and avoid triggering an early election. This could happen if the party successfully navigates the no-confidence motion and maintains enough support in Parliament to continue governing without calling an election before June 15, 2025.

(d) A scenario that results in a Yes outcome is if the opposition parties successfully pass a motion of no confidence after Parliament reconvenes on March 24, 2025, leading to the dissolution of Parliament and an election being called within the specified timeframe. Alternatively, Mark Carney could decide to call an early election to capitalize on any potential boost in popularity or strategic advantage.

Rationale:
The current political climate suggests a heightened possibility of an early election due to the leadership change in the Liberal Party and the opposition's intent to table a no-confidence motion. However, the status quo outcome should be given significant weight, as political systems often resist rapid changes. The new leadership under Mark Carney might seek to stabilize the party and avoid an early election unless strategically advantageous. Given the uncertainty and the potential for strategic maneuvering by both the government and opposition, the probability of an election before June 15, 2025, is not overwhelmingly high but remains plausible.

Probability: 45%

This could be due to strategic considerations, such as allowing more time to close the polling gap with the Conservatives or to complete candidate nominations.

(d) A scenario that results in a Yes outcome could involve the opposition parties successfully tabling a motion of no confidence in the Liberal government once Parliament reconvenes on March 24, 2025. This would trigger an early election, potentially scheduled within the specified timeframe.

Rationale:
Given the current information, the status quo outcome leans towards a "No" as there is no official election announcement yet. However, there are significant political dynamics at play, including the potential for a no-confidence motion and the strategic considerations of the new Liberal leadership under Mark Carney. The opposition's strong position in the polls and their readiness to push for an early election add weight to the possibility of a "Yes" outcome. Nonetheless, the world changes slowly, and without concrete developments, the probability of a "No" remains higher.

Final Answer: Probability: 60%

questions.question_text: Will Ukraine and Russia hold official face-to-face peace negotiations before June 1, 2025?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if before June 1, 2025, credible international news sources report that official representatives of the Ukrainian and Russian governments have held at least one face-to-face meeting specifically designated as peace negotiations. It will resolve as **No** if no such meeting is reported by that date.
questions.fine_print:
- 'Official representatives' must include government officials authorized to negotiate on behalf of their respective countries.
- Meetings must be explicitly for the purpose of negotiating peace or a ceasefire, not merely diplomatic exchanges on other matters.
- Meetings of lower-level officials or working groups preparing for higher-level negotiations count if they are officially designated as part of the peace process.
- Virtual meetings do not count; the negotiations must be in-person.
questions.background_information: In early 2025, there have been increasing diplomatic efforts to end the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Ukrainian President Zelensky has indicated a willingness to negotiate, including potentially discussing territorial exchanges [2](https://www.atalayar.com/en/articulo/politics/zelensky-is-willing-to-negotiate-territory-swap-with-russia/20250212121500211167.html#:~:text=Regarding%20the%20negotiations%2C%20Putin%20has,not%20completely%20under%20Moscow%27s%20control.)[14](https://www.atalayar.com/en/articulo/politics/zelensky-is-willing-to-negotiate-territory-swap-with-russia/20250212121500211167.html#:~:text=Ukraine%20has%20the%20largest%20reserves,not%20completely%20under%20Moscow%27s%20control.). The Trump administration has been pushing for a quick resolution, with National Security Advisor Mike Waltz speaking of private diplomatic efforts [8](https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/10/europe/trump-zelensky-ukraine-russia-analysis-intl/index.html#:~:text=The%20Kremlin%20has%20hinted%20at,any%20truce%20can%20take%20hold.). Keith Kellogg, a Trump advisor, has outlined a potential peace plan involving a ceasefire, followed by possible European peacekeepers along the frontlines [7](https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/10/europe/trump-zelensky-ukraine-russia-analysis-intl/index.html#:~:text=Unusually%2C%20Kellogg%E2%80%99s%20blueprint%20for%20peace,for%20the%20country%20in%20August.)[8](https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/10/europe/trump-zelensky-ukraine-russia-analysis-intl/index.html#:~:text=The%20Kremlin%20has%20hinted%20at,any%20truce%20can%20take%20hold.). According to some reports, a potential timetable suggested a ceasefire around Easter in late April 2025 and a peace conference in May [7](https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/10/europe/trump-zelensky-ukraine-russia-analysis-intl/index.html#:~:text=Unusually%2C%20Kellogg%E2%80%99s%20blueprint%20for%20peace,for%20the%20country%20in%20August.). However, there remain significant obstacles, with Russia demanding Ukraine recognize territorial claims over four eastern and southern regions [2](https://www.atalayar.com/en/articulo/politics/zelensky-is-willing-to-negotiate-territory-swap-with-russia/20250212121500211167.html#:~:text=Regarding%20the%20negotiations%2C%20Putin%20has,not%20completely%20under%20Moscow%27s%20control.)[14](https://www.atalayar.com/en/articulo/politics/zelensky-is-willing-to-negotiate-territory-swap-with-russia/20250212121500211167.html#:~:text=Ukraine%20has%20the%20largest%20reserves,not%20completely%20under%20Moscow%27s%20control.), while Ukrainian military officers have expressed skepticism about any peace deal that doesn't meet Ukraine's core demands [12](https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/ukraine-president-says-wont-accept-peace-deal-between-trump-and-putin-heres-why-101739459592138.html#:~:text=But%20she%20was%20sceptical%20about,for%20more%20Western%20military%20aid.).

questions.question_text: How many G20 countries will submit new or updated climate action plans (NDCs) to the UNFCCC by June 1, 2025?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as the count of G20 member countries that have submitted new or updated Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) between January 1, 2025, and June 1, 2025, as reported on the UNFCCC NDC Registry website (https://unfccc.int/NDCREG).
questions.fine_print:
- Only submissions formally recognized and published on the UNFCCC NDC Registry will be counted.
- Both new NDCs and updates to existing NDCs will count toward the total.
- If a country submits multiple updates within this period, it will only be counted once.
- The G20 consists of 19 countries plus the European Union. For this question, the EU will count as one entity, making the maximum possible count 20.
- If the UNFCCC changes its reporting system or website, the resolution will be based on the equivalent official source.
questions.background_information: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) are the primary means through which countries communicate their climate action commitments under the Paris Agreement. According to a statement by the UN Climate Chief in February 2025, "The vast majority of countries have indicated they will submit new plans this year" [10](https://unfccc.int/news/ten-years-since-the-paris-agreement-how-far-we-have-come-the-journey-ahead-un-climate-chief-delivers#:~:text=Harnessing%20the%20power%20of%20cheaper%2C,submit%20new%20plans%20this%20year.). These national plans are described as "among the most important policy documents governments will produce this century" [10](https://unfccc.int/news/ten-years-since-the-paris-agreement-how-far-we-have-come-the-journey-ahead-un-climate-chief-delivers#:~:text=Harnessing%20the%20power%20of%20cheaper%2C,submit%20new%20plans%20this%20year.). The submissions in 2025 are particularly significant as they mark the ten-year anniversary of the Paris Agreement [10](https://unfccc.int/news/ten-years-since-the-paris-agreement-how-far-we-have-come-the-journey-ahead-un-climate-chief-delivers#:~:text=Harnessing%20the%20power%20of%20cheaper%2C,submit%20new%20plans%20this%20year.). The G20 countries are responsible for approximately 80% of global greenhouse gas emissions, making their commitments particularly significant for global climate goals. The UNFCCC was established to stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which it pursues through an annual Conference of the Parties (COP) [13](https://education.cfr.org/learn/reading/international-agreements-climate#:~:text=Its%20main%20objective%20is%20to,international%20action%20on%20environmental%20development.).

questions.question_text: Which party will win the most seats in the Australian Senate election by May 17, 2025?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve based on the official results of the Australian Senate election, as reported by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) at https://www.aec.gov.au/. The party that wins the most seats out of the contested half of the Senate (38 seats) will be the resolution.
questions.fine_print:
- If two or more parties win exactly the same number of seats, the question will resolve to the option with the highest total national first-preference vote.
- Coalition parties (Liberal and National) will be counted together if they run as a formal coalition.
- Independent candidates will be counted collectively under 'Other'.
- If the election is postponed beyond June 17, 2025, this question will be annulled.
questions.background_information: Australia will hold parliamentary elections in 2025, with the Senate election required to be held by May 17, 2025 [1](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=While%20Canadian%20law%20requires%20the,be%20chosen%20by%20Sept.%2027.)[6](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=Poilievre%E2%80%99s%20party%20is%20expected%20to,be%20decided%20by%20May%2017.). Half of the 76 seats in Australia's Senate will be up for election, with 38 seats being contested [6](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=Poilievre%E2%80%99s%20party%20is%20expected%20to,be%20decided%20by%20May%2017.). The Senate election is separate from the House of Representatives election, which must be held by September 27, 2025 [1](https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2025-01-03/5-elections-around-the-world-to-watch-in-2025#:~:text=While%20Canadian%20law%20requires%20the,be%20chosen%20by%20Sept.%2027.). The Australian Senate uses a proportional representation voting system, which typically results in a diverse range of parties winning seats. Currently, the Senate is composed of members from the Liberal-National Coalition, Australian Labor Party, Australian Greens, and various minor parties and independents.

*Total Cost*: $0.05

## Report 1 Summary
### Forecasts
*Forecaster 1*:

- Australian Greens: 10.0%

*Forecaster 5*:

- Australian Labor Party: 50.0%
- Australian Greens: 15.0%
- Other: 5.0%



### Research Summary
The research presents a range of insights and polling data regarding the upcoming Australian Senate election scheduled for May 17, 2025. A poll by RedBridge indicates that a significant portion of the electorate blames the current Labor government for rising electricity costs, with 53% attributing their financial struggles to Labor's renewable energy policies. Meanwhile, the Coalition's stance on nuclear energy has not gained traction, as public perception of nuclear safety has worsened. The polling landscape shows Labor at a primary vote of 68.5% and the Coalition at 29.4%, marking a notable decline in their combined vote share. The rise of independent candidates and minor parties is also evident, suggesting a fragmentation of traditional party support.

Additionally, the potential for a hung parliament is highlighted, with the Labor Party expected to lose seats while the Coalition may struggle to gain a majority even if it wins additional seats. Key battlegrounds are identified, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, where both major parties face challenges from independents and minor parties. The Greens maintain a stable national support of around 12%, which could influence Senate outcomes but may not translate to significant gains in the lower house. Overall, the research underscores a complex electoral landscape characterized by shifting voter sentiments and the potential for a minority government. 

Sources:
- [Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-14512711/Anthony-Albanese-energy-bill-redbridge-poll.html)
- [Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-03-19/adam-bandt-greens-vote-federal-election/105067990)
- [The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/3/17/n14460769.htm)
- [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/ng-interactive/2025/mar/18/australian-election-2025-polls-today-opinion-poll-tracker-essential-newspoll-2pp-party-labor-coalition-anthony-albanese-peter-dutton-latest)
- [nichigopress.jp](https://nichigopress.jp/news-item/164314/)
- [Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-03-09/wa-election-result-lessons-for-labor-liberals-analysis/105028434)
- [insidestory.org.au](https://insidestory.org.au/disruption-with-australian-characteristics/)
- [Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-14416259/Anthony-Albanese-hits-reporter-asking-boring-question.html)
- [katherinetimes.com.au](https://www.katherinetimes.com.au/story/8885626/key-regional-battlegrounds-seats-in-australias-federal-election/?cs=9676)
- [rappler.com](https://www.rappler.com/voices/thought-leaders/newsstand-survey-says-history-will-repeat-itself-senatorial-surveys-2025/)
- [Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-01-28/federal-election-when-called-and-where-will-it-be-fought/104825066)
- [The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/1/27/n14423209.htm)


# RESEARCH
## Report 1 Research
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Poll blames Albo for huge cost-of-living issue**
A new poll by RedBridge has found that over half of Australians blame Anthony Albanese's Labor government for their soaring electricity bills, with 53% of voters strongly agreeing or agreeing that Labor's renewable energy policy has pushed their power bills up. The poll also found that Peter Dutton's pro-nuclear stance has failed to win voters over, with the number of Aussies who believe nuclear is unsafe increasing from 35% to 39% over the past year. RedBridge director Tony Barry said the Coalition needs to 'own the economic narrative' to win voters ahead of the election, while Kosmos Samaras, a former Labor strategist, predicted a complex election where the two main parties might race to 70 seats in the House of Representatives rather than 76. 'Basically people are blaming governments and it doesn't matter who is in government they are going to wear the brunt of voters stressed about power bills,' Mr Samaras said. The poll also revealed that 57% of Labor voters believed Australia was headed in the right direction, while 72% of Coalition voters believed the country was heading in the wrong direction.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 10:02 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-14512711/Anthony-Albanese-energy-bill-redbridge-poll.html)

**Do you recognise this man? Nearly a third of his voters don't**
A recent survey by Redbridge found that nearly a third of voters who support the Greens do not know who their leader, Adam Bandt, is. Despite this, Bandt enjoys a strong primary vote in his seat of Melbourne, with 50.1% of voters supporting him. The survey also found that younger voters are highly disengaged from politics, with many not following the news or reading newspapers. As a result, politicians are now targeting social media platforms and podcasts to reach these voters. The Greens are also diversifying their policy focus, including on housing, Palestine, and the AUKUS alliance, in an effort to lift their brand awareness and win more seats in the lower house. However, Labor has ruled out a formal deal with the Greens, which may limit their ability to win seats. The survey found that the Greens' national support remains at around 12%, which is enough to secure a strong result in the Senate but not enough to win in the lower house.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 06:00 PM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-03-19/adam-bandt-greens-vote-federal-election/105067990)

**Australian Opposition Leader Considers Referendum to Deport Dual Nationals**
Australian opposition leader Peter Dutton has confirmed that if his party wins the election, they will consider holding a referendum to allow the government to deport dual nationals convicted of crimes. Dutton stated, 'You can't go beyond the constitution.' The proposal would give government ministers the power to decide on deportations, but has raised concerns about the government's power. The cost of the referendum has also been a point of contention. Treasurer Jim Chalmers criticized Dutton's move, saying it was an attempt to divert attention from other issues. Senator Jacqui Lambie also expressed concerns, calling the proposal 'expensive and divisive.' However, some within the party have expressed support for the proposal, including Senator Bridget McKenzie, who said, 'The constitution gives us an important mechanism, that if we want to change the constitution, we should ask every Australian citizen for their opinion.' 
Original language: zh
Publish date: March 18, 2025 02:00 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/3/17/n14460769.htm)

**Australian election 2025 polls tracker: Labor v Coalition latest opinion polling results**
As the 2025 Australian federal election approaches, political polls are being released regularly. The polls show a range of support for the Labor and Coalition parties, with a significant decline in their combined primary vote share. The Labor party is currently polling at 68.5% primary votes, while the Coalition is at 29.4%. The polls also show a significant increase in support for independents and other parties. The charts below show the two-party preferred vote since 2022, as well as the primary votes for Labor, the Coalition, Greens and others/independents. The polls also provide demographic information, including age, sex, location and education. According to the polls, Labor is leading in most demographics, but the Coalition is performing well among certain groups. 'The 68.5% primary votes share for Labor and the Coalition is an all time low and the continuation of a steady decline since the two parties claimed 98% of votes in 1951,' said the article. 'The chart below shows the primary votes for Labor, the Coalition, Greens and others/independents. It is based on the same model as our main tracker, starting with the vote share at the last election.'
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 12:48 AM
Source:[The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/ng-interactive/2025/mar/18/australian-election-2025-polls-today-opinion-poll-tracker-essential-newspoll-2pp-party-labor-coalition-anthony-albanese-peter-dutton-latest)

**Will a Grand Coalition with the CDU Save Germany?**
The 2025 German federal election resulted in the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) winning the most seats, while the Alternative for Germany (AfD) nearly doubled its representation. However, the outcome raises questions about whether a potential coalition government with Friedrich Merz will improve the country's situation. The Social Democratic Party (SPD) and the Greens lost votes, while the Free Democratic Party (FDP) and the Blue and White Party (BSW) failed to secure seats in the new Bundestag. The Left Party gained ground among young voters, outperforming the AfD in this demographic.
Original language: de
Publish date: March 17, 2025 10:18 PM
Source:[Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen](https://www.zdf.de/video/talk/13-fragen-102/bundestagswahl-2025-106)

**Australian Federal Election Expected to Result in Hung Parliament**
According to a recent poll by 'NewsPoll' and published in 'The Australian', the Australian federal election, scheduled for May 3, 10, or 17, is expected to result in a 'hung parliament'. The poll, conducted from March 3-7, shows that the center-left Labor Party, the current ruling party, maintains a 49% support rate, while the center-right Liberal Party, the main opposition, has a 51% support rate. If the actual election results reflect the poll's findings, the Labor Party would lose 3% of its votes compared to the previous election, resulting in a loss of 7 seats and a total of 70 seats in the 151-member House of Representatives, falling short of the majority (76 seats). Meanwhile, the Liberal Party, with 53 seats, would not be able to form a majority government even if it were to win all 7 seats lost by the Labor Party. In such a scenario, the election would result in a hung parliament, and the party with the most seats would need to form a coalition with smaller parties or independents to gain a majority. This would lead to a highly unstable parliamentary situation, with the ruling party relying on the support of smaller parties to maintain power.
Original language: ja
Publish date: March 10, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[nichigopress.jp](https://nichigopress.jp/news-item/164314/)

**Emotional Roger Cook says huge election win a 'vindication'**
Western Australian Premier Roger Cook declared his party's landslide victory a 'vindication' of their plans for the state. Despite a statewide swing against Labor of over 18%, the party maintained an overwhelming majority in the lower house. Cook said, 'This is an emphatic victory for WA Labor and it's a vindication of the strong government that we have provided for the people of Western Australia.' Liberal leader Libby Mettam faced reporters, leaving open the possibility she would step down from the role. Mettam said, 'Whoever the leader is going into the 2029 election they need four years to work as a leader, to build momentum in the community and to have the support of the Liberal Party going forward as well.' The Nationals have won four seats and are seeking a closer alliance with the Liberals to beat Labor in the 2029 election.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 09, 2025 04:54 AM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-03-09/wa-state-election-2025-roger-cook-vindication/105029318)

**The lessons in Labor's big win, as Liberals face another existential crisis**
The Australian Labor Party (ALP) has won the 2025 Western Australian state election, securing 41 seats and retaining its majority. The Liberal Party, on the other hand, has seen a significant decline, with only four seats and a reduced presence in the lower house. According to pollster Kos Samaras, the swing against Labor was 17%, but only 5% of that swing went back to the Liberals, while 1% went to the Nationals. The remaining swing splintered across minor parties and independents, particularly among millennials in the outer suburbs. Samaras attributed this to the cost-of-living pressures and the progressive views of this demographic. The Liberal Party's losses were significant, particularly in seats like Warren-Blackwood, Bateman, Scarborough, and South Perth, which were expected to be easy wins. Labor's victory is seen as a major win, with an emphatic mandate to continue its policy agenda, but it may lose its majority in the upper house and be forced to negotiate with a new-look crossbench. 'The best Labor branch in the country' is how pollster Kos Samaras described WA Labor, citing its ability to win elections and suburban politics.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 08, 2025 09:16 PM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-03-09/wa-election-result-lessons-for-labor-liberals-analysis/105028434)

**Disruption (with Australian characteristics) • Brett Evans**
The 2025 federal election in Australia may result in a minority government, with the Liberal Party's chances of winning a majority being threatened by the rise of teal independents. The teal movement, led by independent candidates such as Nicolette Boele in the seat of Bradfield, has been gaining momentum, with some polls predicting a 98% chance of minority government. The teals have been successful in winning seats previously held by the Liberal Party, and their numbers are expected to increase in the upcoming election. If the polls are correct, the politicians of Australia will be facing a hung parliament, and the horse-trading will begin. The article also explores the history of minority government in Australia, citing the example of the 1941 election, where two independents brought down the government and led to the election of John Curtin as prime minister. The article concludes that minority government may not be such a bad thing, and that it could bring about better policy ideas and a more representative government.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 07, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[insidestory.org.au](https://insidestory.org.au/disruption-with-australian-characteristics/)

**Anthony Albanese hits back at reporter after asking 'boring' question**
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese responded sharply to a journalist's question about the date of the upcoming election, calling it 'so boring'. The election must be held on or before May 17, and experts consider April 12 the most likely date. However, this date coincides with the AFL Gather Round in Adelaide, which may affect voters who will be traveling and unable to cast their ballots. Albanese emphasized his support for four-year fixed terms, but noted that the Liberal Party has opposed referendums to implement this. Senator David Pocock has called for the election date to be legislated, stating that 'constant election date speculation is a waste of time'.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2025 07:33 AM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-14416259/Anthony-Albanese-hits-reporter-asking-boring-question.html)

**Federal Election 2025: The marginal seats that will decide the election**
The upcoming federal election in Australia is expected to be a close contest between the Coalition and Labor. Election analyst Ben Raue said there is an 'increasing urban-rural divide' and the Coalition is gaining ground in regional areas. The Coalition needs 19 seats for a majority government and the polls suggest the race is tightening. Key marginal seats include Robertson, Dobell, and Gilmore in New South Wales, as well as Paterson, Hunter, and Shortland in the Hunter region. The Nationals are hopeful of snatching back Calare and Cowper, while Labor's Kristy McBain holds Eden-Monaro on a 6.1 per cent margin. In Victoria, the Coalition is hoping to win back McEwen, Corangamite, and Wannon, while Labor's Susan Templeman holds Macquarie on a 6.3 per cent margin. Pollster Kos Samaras predicts the Coalition to pick up six seats, with 12-14 at this point too close to call. 'It will be the closest race we have seen so far because of the fragmenting of the two-party vote,' he said.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2025 08:00 PM
Source:[katherinetimes.com.au](https://www.katherinetimes.com.au/story/8885626/key-regional-battlegrounds-seats-in-australias-federal-election/?cs=9676)

**[Newsstand] ‘Survey says?’ History will repeat itself**
According to recent surveys by Pulse Asia and Octa Research, the ruling coalition is expected to dominate the 2025 Senate elections. The surveys show that 10 out of 14 candidates with a statistical chance of winning for Pulse Asia and 12 out of 16 for Octa are from the administration slate. This pattern is consistent with historical data, where the incumbent president's party has consistently won a majority of Senate seats in mid-term elections. However, voters may seek balance in the Senate, as seen in past elections where opposition candidates and independents have been elected. Dr. Ronald Holmes, president of Pulse Asia, noted that the top quarter of candidates seems to be more stable, with Erwin Tulfo leading with 62.8%, followed by Bong Go and Tito Sotto. Professor Ranjit Rye, president of Octa, cautioned that it's premature to make predictions, but noted that candidates with ratings above 40% have a high probability of winning. Rye also mentioned a surge in ratings for TV host and entertainer Ogie Revillame, who he believes has a high chance of winning.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2025 02:00 AM
Source:[rappler.com](https://www.rappler.com/voices/thought-leaders/newsstand-survey-says-history-will-repeat-itself-senatorial-surveys-2025/)

**The seats that will determine if Albanese or Dutton is the next prime minister**
The upcoming federal election in Australia will be a closely contested battle between Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's Labor Party and the Coalition. Labor currently holds 78 seats, while the Coalition has 57. The Greens and independents hold 15 seats. To win a majority, Labor needs to lose only two seats, while the Coalition needs to win 19 seats. Key battlegrounds include Victoria, where Labor faces threats from the Greens and Liberals, and New South Wales, where Labor is facing issues in the mortgage belt. Tasmania could also be a surprise battleground, with both Labor and the Coalition seeing potential for gains. In Western Australia, Labor faces a high-profile three-cornered contest in the new seat of Bullwinkel. In Queensland, Labor has a poor track record, holding only five of the state's 26 seats. The Coalition is eyeing off two Greens seats, having previously held both. Labor currently holds all five lower house seats in the ACT and NT, but faces a tough battle in the NT seat of Lingiari. Independent David Pocock is likely to face a challenge in the ACT Senate seat. Former Victorian Liberal director Tony Barry estimates the Coalition could win seven seats in various states, while political observers estimate the opposition will need around half a dozen gains in Victoria to govern in majority. 
Original language: en
Publish date: January 27, 2025 07:00 PM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-01-28/federal-election-when-called-and-where-will-it-be-fought/104825066)

**Albanese Remains Confident in Labor's Chances Despite Latest Newspoll**
Despite most voters believing the Liberal Party will win the upcoming federal election, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says his goal remains to form a majority government, which he acknowledges will be a difficult process. According to the latest Newspoll survey, 53% of voters believe the Liberal Party will win, compared to 47% who support the Labor Party. In terms of two-party preferred voting, the Liberal Party has a 2% lead over the Labor Party government, up from 1% in the previous survey. Albanese remains confident in Labor's chances of winning, saying, 'A Labor victory is precious because, since federation, Labor has only been in office for about a third of the time or less.' 'We currently have 78 seats, and we will work hard to form a majority Labor government, and I believe we can do it. We will fight for it every day, making sure people understand the significance of this election.' The federal election must be held by May 17 at the latest. The Newspoll survey shows that the government's support rate has dropped by 3.1% since the 2022 election. Labor's primary vote support rate has dropped by 2% since December last year, to 31%, while the Liberal Party's support rate remains stable at 39%. Former Deputy Prime Minister and National Party MP Barnaby Joyce said on 7News: 'I won't say we're home and hosed, but it's clear that people are very unhappy with Albanese.' 'The cost of living has crushed them, and they've failed to effectively address it. Instead, they've been obsessed with intermittent energy and other useless things.'
Original language: zh

questions.question_text: What percentage of global jet fuel consumption will be sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by June 1, 2025?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve based on the most recent official data published before June 15, 2025, by either the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), the International Air Transport Association (IATA), or another globally recognized aviation authority that tracks sustainable aviation fuel usage. The percentage will be calculated as the volume of sustainable aviation fuels consumed divided by the total volume of jet fuel consumed worldwide.
questions.fine_print:
- Only SAF that meets internationally recognized sustainability criteria will count toward the total.
- If different authoritative sources provide different figures, the resolution will use the average of the three most credible available figures.
- If no precise percentage is available by the resolution date, this question will resolve based on the most recent available data prior to June 15, 2025.
- If no data is available at all, the question will be annulled.
questions.background_information: In February 2025, the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) delivered a global framework to implement a clean energy transition for international aviation [9](https://www.icao.int/Newsroom/Pages/ICAO-Conference-delivers-strong-global-framework-to-implement-a-clean-energy-transition-for-international-aviation.aspx#:~:text=%E2%80%9CInvestors%2C%20governments%20and%20others%20all,the%20ICAO%20Assembly%20in%202022.)[11](https://www.icao.int/Newsroom/Pages/ICAO-Conference-delivers-strong-global-framework-to-implement-a-clean-energy-transition-for-international-aviation.aspx#:~:text=It%20has%20been%20designed%20to,socio%2Deconomic%20prosperity%20wherever%20aircraft%20fly.). This framework was designed to support the aviation sector's energy transition and achieve the goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, as adopted by the ICAO Assembly in 2022 [9](https://www.icao.int/Newsroom/Pages/ICAO-Conference-delivers-strong-global-framework-to-implement-a-clean-energy-transition-for-international-aviation.aspx#:~:text=%E2%80%9CInvestors%2C%20governments%20and%20others%20all,the%20ICAO%20Assembly%20in%202022.). The framework aims to send a steady signal to public and private investors, as well as fuel producers, on the opportunities to support the aviation sector's energy transition [11](https://www.icao.int/Newsroom/Pages/ICAO-Conference-delivers-strong-global-framework-to-implement-a-clean-energy-transition-for-international-aviation.aspx#:~:text=It%20has%20been%20designed%20to,socio%2Deconomic%20prosperity%20wherever%20aircraft%20fly.). Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) are a key component of the aviation industry's strategy to reduce carbon emissions, as they can be produced from sustainable sources such as waste oils, agricultural residues, or captured carbon, and can reduce lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional jet fuel. As of early 2025, SAF represents less than 1% of global jet fuel consumption, but many airlines and governments have committed to increasing its use significantly in the coming years.

questions.question_text: Will the ECB cut interest rates at least twice more by June 6, 2025?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if the European Central Bank announces at least two reductions to its key interest rates (specifically the deposit facility rate) between March 19, 2025, and June 6, 2025, according to official ECB announcements on their website or official press releases.
questions.fine_print:
- The current deposit facility rate is 3.25% as of January 2025.
- Each reduction must be formally announced by the ECB Governing Council.
- Technical adjustments that do not represent monetary policy decisions will not count.
- If the ECB changes its framework for interest rates such that the deposit facility rate is no longer used, this question will be resolved based on the equivalent main policy rate.
questions.background_information:
The European Central Bank reduced interest rates in January 2025, marking the first rate cut of the year after the four reductions in 2024 [9](https://www.ccn.com/analysis/business/ecb-projected-rate-rise-5-years/#:~:text=The%20European%20Central%20Bank%20reduced,scheduled%20for%20Mar.%206%2C%202025.). According to a Reuters survey, economists expect the ECB to cut rates four more times by mid-year 2025 [7](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/ecb-cut-rates-four-more-times-by-mid-year-say-economists-2025-01-15/#:~:text=Inflation%20was%20expected%20to%20drop,downgrade%20from%20predictions%20in%20October.).

Inflation in the Eurozone was at 2.5% in January 2025 and slightly decreased to 2.4% in February 2025, according to Eurostat flash estimates [13](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2025/764374/ECTI_IDA(2025)764374_EN.pdf#:~:text=According%20to%20the%20latest%20Eurostat,January.%20Core%20inflation%2C%20which%20excludes). The ECB's target is 2.0%, which inflation was expected to reach in Q2 2025 [7](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/ecb-cut-rates-four-more-times-by-mid-year-say-economists-2025-01-15/#:~:text=Inflation%20was%20expected%20to%20drop,downgrade%20from%20predictions%20in%20October.).

The ECB has stated that it is not pre-committing to a particular rate path and will make decisions based on incoming data, underlying inflation dynamics, and the strength of monetary policy transmission [3](https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/pdf/ecbu/eb202501.en.pdf#:~:text=data%2C%20the%20dynamics%20of%20underlying,all%20of%20its%20instruments%20within). However, there are concerns about potential inflation risks, with a majority of economists believing inflation might be higher than expected [7](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/ecb-cut-rates-four-more-times-by-mid-year-say-economists-2025-01-15/#:~:text=Inflation%20was%20expected%20to%20drop,downgrade%20from%20predictions%20in%20October.).

forecast_report.explanation:
# SUMMARY
*Question*: Will the ECB cut interest rates at least twice more by June 6, 2025?
*Final Prediction*: 80.0%
*Total Cost*: $0.06
*Time Spent*: 0.32 minutes


## Report 1 Summary
### Forecasts
*Forecaster 1*: 75.0%
*Forecaster 2*: 80.0%
*Forecaster 3*: 70.0%
*Forecaster 4*: 80.0%
*Forecaster 5*: 80.0%


### Research Summary
The research indicates that the European Central Bank (ECB) has been actively cutting interest rates, having lowered the deposit rate to 2.5% as of March 6, 2025, marking its sixth cut since June 2024. Analysts expect the ECB to implement two more rate cuts in April and June 2025, although there is a consensus that the deposit rate will stabilize at 2% thereafter. The ECB's recent decision to cut rates is attributed to easing inflation concerns, with the Eurozone's inflation rate revised down to 2.3% for February 2025. Despite these cuts, there are warnings from some economists about potential inflationary pressures due to increased government spending, which could limit further rate reductions.

Market expectations are mixed, with some analysts predicting a pause in rate cuts as economic conditions evolve, particularly in light of rising uncertainty regarding trade policies and fiscal measures. The ECB has emphasized that it will assess incoming data before making further decisions, and while there is a significant expectation for rate cuts in the near term, the potential for inflation to rise could complicate the ECB's monetary policy strategy moving forward. Overall, the research highlights the delicate balance the ECB must maintain between stimulating economic growth and managing inflation risks.


# RESEARCH
## Report 1 Research
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Eurozone Inflation Rate Downgraded to 2.3% in February**
The European Union's statistics agency reported that the Eurozone's consumer price index (HICP) rose by 2.3% in February compared to the same period last year, a slight downward revision from the initial estimate of 2.4%. The revision was mainly due to a correction in the German indicator. This may alleviate concerns that the strong inflationary pressure could prevent the European Central Bank (ECB) from further cutting interest rates. The core inflation rate, excluding food and energy, remained at 2.6%. The market expects a 50-60% probability of a rate cut by the ECB in April, with a complete expectation of rate cuts until June. The ECB currently expects inflation to remain at current levels throughout the year and to decline to its 2% target by the first quarter of 2026.
Original language: ja
Publish date: March 19, 2025 10:35 AM
Source:[ニューズウィーク日本版 オフィシャルサイト](https://www.newsweekjapan.jp/headlines/business/2025/03/542672.php)

**Euro zone February inflation estimate reduced due to Germany revision**
Eurostat revised down the estimated inflation rate for the euro zone in February to 2.3%, mainly due to a revision in Germany. This easing of inflation concerns may not significantly impact the European Central Bank's (ECB) decision on interest rate cuts. The ECB has stated that it will not make a decision until it has collected more data, taking into account factors such as trade tensions, budget spending, and falling energy costs. Markets currently anticipate a 50-60% chance of a rate cut in April, with another cut expected before the end of the year, potentially taking the ECB's deposit rate to 2%. The ECB expects inflation to remain around the current level for the rest of the year before falling to its 2% target in the first quarter of 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 19, 2025 10:28 AM
Source:[Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/euro-zone-february-inflation-estimate-reduced-due-germany-revision-2025-03-19/)

**Potential Euro (EUR) Rise Amid Federal Reserve's Dovish Signals**
Analysts predict that if the Federal Reserve's dot plot indicates a faster pace of policy easing, the euro (EUR) could rise further. The euro has been testing the $1.09 mark and may appreciate due to the U.S. economy's weakness, which could lead the Fed to lower its median interest rate expectation for 2025 from 3.9% to 3.6%. The euro's trajectory also depends on the European Central Bank's (ECB) actions, with the ECB unlikely to rush into another rate cut in April. However, a rate cut in June is possible, and the euro could potentially reach the $1.11 level, the pre-Trump trade shock level in Q4, but any appreciation might stall before the White House's proposed 'reciprocal tariffs' take effect on April 2.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 19, 2025 08:23 AM
Source:[GuruFocus](https://www.gurufocus.com/news/2742471/potential-euro-eur-rise-amid-federal-reserves-dovish-signals)

**Banks Adjust Daily Deposit Interest Rates in Response to ECB Decision**
The European Central Bank has decided to lower the base interest rate to 2.50% on March 6, 2025, aiming to achieve a stable inflation rate of 2% or less. In response, banks are adjusting their daily deposit interest rates downward. The best current offer for daily deposits is 3.05% at the Nürnberger Consorsbank, with a quarterly payout and a three-month guarantee. Other banks offering competitive rates include the ING (3.0% for four months), Openbank (3.0% for three months), Bigbank (2.95% for four months), Stellantis Direktbank (2.95% for three months), TF Bank (2.95% for three months), Advanzia Bank (2.90% for three months), Ford Money (2.9% for three months), Suresse Direkt Bank (2.90% for four months), Opel Direktbank (2.8% for three months), 1822direkt (2.75% for four months), Barclays (2.75% for three months), Raiffeisenbank im Hochtaunus (2.75% for four months), Renault Bank (2.7% for three months), Bunq (2.67% for three months), Volkswagen Financial Services (2.6% for six months), N26 (2.5% for six months), Postbank (2.5% for four months), Klarna (2.4% for three months), wiLLBe (2.4% for three months), Santander (2.3% for four months), Akbank AG (2.25% for three months), Bank11 (2.25% for three months), and Targobank (2.25% for four months).
Original language: de
Publish date: March 18, 2025 08:20 AM
Source:[Focus](https://www.focus.de/finanzen/banken/tagesgeld-zinsticker-tagesgeld-zinsen-im-freien-fall-eine-bank-bietet-noch-3-05-prozent_id_125594616.html)

**Austrians Prioritize Debt Repayment Over Consumption Amidst Low Interest Rates**
Austrians have been using their increased household income in 2024 to pay off existing debts rather than consuming. However, the decreasing interest rates are causing a surge in demand for credit. To mitigate this risk, nearly 90% of new home construction loans in 2024 were fixed-rate loans. The European Central Bank's (ECB) interest rate cut in the past week was a welcome news for borrowers, but a less pleasant one for savers. The ECB has been gradually reducing the base rate from 4% to 2.5% since June 2024. According to Edeltraud Stiftinger, Vice-Governor of the Oesterreichische Nationalbank (OeNB), the interest rate cuts will be passed on to customers in a similar magnitude. The difference between the interest rates charged by banks for loans and the interest rates paid on deposits has remained relatively unchanged in Austria, averaging 1.56 percentage points in 2024. The interest rate spread in new business remained low, at 1.56 percentage points, similar to the previous years. With the decreasing interest rates, the demand for home construction loans is increasing, with a new credit volume of 6.2 billion euros in the second half of 2024, up from 4.9 billion euros in the same period in 2023. However, most borrowers are opting for fixed-rate loans, as they are still cheaper than variable interest rates. In 2024, only 11% of new home construction loans had variable interest rates, down from 40% in 2019. The OeNB emphasizes the importance of transparency and advises borrowers to choose a financing option that they can afford in the long term.
Original language: de
Publish date: March 17, 2025 02:12 PM
Source:[Die Presse](https://www.diepresse.com/19478045/oesterreicher-zahlten-lieber-schulden-zurueck-statt-zu-konsumieren)

**EZB to Lower Interest Rates Further, but Not Below 2%**
The European Central Bank (EZB) has lowered interest rates six times since the monetary policy shift in summer 2024. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg expect two more interest rate cuts in April and June, but do not expect interest rates to fall below 2%. The current deposit rate of 2.5% is expected to remain at 2% by the end of the survey period. EZB observers do not expect another interest rate cut in the next year, as they believe that increased spending will increase inflation by the end of 2026. Some experts, such as Marco Wagner from Commerzbank, warn that the EZB may be forced to raise interest rates again at their next meeting. However, others, like Olli Rehn, believe that there is no need to slow down the easing of monetary policy. 'The spending will increase the inflation pressure by the end of 2026,' said Wagner. 'It is not necessarily necessary to slow down the easing,' said Rehn. 'We expect two more interest rate cuts in April and June,' said the analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. 'However, we do not expect interest rates to fall below 2%,' they added.
Original language: de
Publish date: March 17, 2025 11:03 AM
Source:[finanzmarktwelt.de](https://finanzmarktwelt.de/ezb-senkt-zinsen-weniger-weil-europa-mehr-ausgibt-umfrage-342479/)

**European Central Bank Expected to Lower Interest Rates Twice in 2025**
The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to lower interest rates twice in 2025, in April and June, according to market surveys. However, analysts believe that the deposit rate will remain stable at 2% after the cut, and will not be lowered further. Some economists had previously predicted that the rate could drop to 1.75% in March 2026, but the market is now concerned that the increased government spending in Europe could lead to higher inflation, limiting further easing. The ECB has already implemented six rate cuts in the past year to combat slowing inflation and weak economic growth. Market analysts still expect the rate cuts in April and June, but the deposit rate may remain unchanged after reaching 2%. This adjustment in market expectations is largely due to the increased government spending in Europe. Germany's Commerzbank economist Marco Wagner warned that future inflation pressure may arise by the end of 2026, while Austrian ECB member Robert Holzmann cautioned that there is a possibility of re-raising interest rates in the future. In contrast, Finnish ECB member Olli Rehn believes that the pace of rate cuts does not necessarily need to be slowed down. The market's expectations for further rate cuts have diverged, with some analysts predicting that the ECB may pause rate cuts in April. TD Securities economist said, 'The fiscal stimulus plan is currently being reviewed, and if implemented, it will further boost economic growth.' However, market analysts point out that the increased government spending may push up inflation, and the ECB may therefore be more cautious, avoiding excessive rate cuts that could lead to higher prices again. Market expectations for monetary policy adjustments are changing, with analysts predicting that the eurozone's economic growth rate will be 0.9%, 1.2%, and 1.5% respectively from 2025 to 2027, in line with the ECB's forecast. However, there is still significant uncertainty in the market: the expectation of rate cuts has cooled down, and even a pause in rate cuts in April is possible. Trade tensions may also weigh on the eurozone's economic growth. TD Securities economist said, 'Trade barriers are affecting market expectations.' The latest data shows that the eurozone's inflation expectations for 2025-2027 are 2.2%, 2.0%, and 2.1% respectively, slightly higher than the previous month's forecast, indicating that the market's concerns about future price trends are increasing. In the short term, the weakening of rate cut expectations is reducing the euro's attractiveness: as the ECB is expected to further lower interest rates, the euro's interest rate advantage is narrowing, leading to a flow of funds to assets with higher yields, and the euro's exchange rate is under pressure. Global market risk aversion may support the euro: if the market is concerned about global economic growth or geopolitical tensions, the euro may be supported by risk aversion demand. The dollar's movement will also affect the euro: if the Federal Reserve accelerates rate cuts in the next few months, it may reduce the pressure on the euro to depreciate. Van Luu, head of foreign exchange and fixed income strategy at Russell Investments, said, 'The market expects the euro to be affected by policy and risk aversion sentiment in the short term, and may continue to fluctuate.' Currently, the market's focus is on the ECB's policy adjustment pace and the impact of fiscal stimulus on inflation. If the ECB unexpectedly slows down rate cuts or inflation data exceeds expectations, the euro may receive temporary support; otherwise, if market expectations for further easing continue to rise, the euro may continue to be under pressure. The ECB's policy choices are currently very delicate, as they need to further lower interest rates to support economic growth while also being cautious of the inflation risks brought by fiscal stimulus. In this context, the euro's exchange rate will be affected by policy uncertainty and market sentiment, and may continue to fluctuate in the future. If the eurozone's economic growth fails to meet expectations or inflation pressure continues to rise, the market may question the ECB's policy path, which will affect the euro's trend. Additionally, global market uncertainty, trade tensions, and the dollar's movement will also be important factors affecting the euro's future fluctuations. In the short term, the market will closely watch the ECB's next move, and if policy adjustments exceed market expectations, the euro may experience more significant fluctuations. In the next few months, euro investors need to pay attention to policy signals, inflation data, and global market risks to determine the direction of the exchange rate.

However, Lagarde emphasized that the ECB will not pre-commit to further moves, and will instead assess the data to determine the appropriate course of action. questions.question_text: What will be the Eurozone's headline inflation rate for May 2025 according to Eurostat's flash estimate?
questions.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve to the headline inflation rate (year-on-year percentage change in the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices) for the Eurozone for May 2025, as reported in Eurostat's flash estimate published in late May or early June 2025.
questions.fine_print:
- The value will be expressed as a percentage to one decimal place (e.g., 2.3%).
- If Eurostat publishes a revised figure after the initial flash estimate but before June 17, 2025, the most recent figure will be used for resolution.
- If no flash estimate is published by June 17, 2025, the question will be resolved using the most recently available official Eurostat figure for Eurozone inflation.
questions.background_information:
Eurozone inflation has been gradually decreasing, with the headline inflation rate at 2.5% in January 2025 and 2.4% in February 2025, according to Eurostat flash estimates [13](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2025/764374/ECTI_IDA(2025)764374_EN.pdf#:~:text=According%20to%20the%20latest%20Eurostat,January.%20Core%20inflation%2C%20which%20excludes). The European Central Bank's target is 2.0%, which inflation was expected to reach in Q2 2025 and stay around through Q2 of 2026 [7](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/ecb-cut-rates-four-more-times-by-mid-year-say-economists-2025-01-15/#:~:text=Inflation%20was%20expected%20to%20drop,downgrade%20from%20predictions%20in%20October.).

However, there are several factors that could cause inflation to rise beyond expectations, including wage or profit increases, heightened geopolitical tensions, and scaling up of investments in defense spending, which may drive up energy prices and freight costs [5](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2025/764374/ECTI_IDA(2025)764374_EN.pdf#:~:text=in%202025.%20Inflation%20could%20rise,but%20also%20put%20an%20additional). According to the latest Survey of Professional Forecasters for Q1 2025, there have been upward revisions to headline inflation forecasts for 2025 [12](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2025/764374/ECTI_IDA(2025)764374_EN.pdf#:~:text=pressure%20on%20aggregate%20demand%2C%20thus,revisions%20in%20the%20long%20term.).

When economists were asked whether inflation would more likely be higher or lower than expected, a majority (20 out of 34) said higher [7](https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/ecb-cut-rates-four-more-times-by-mid-year-say-economists-2025-01-15/#:~:text=Inflation%20was%20expected%20to%20drop,downgrade%20from%20predictions%20in%20October.). The ECB remains vigilant and has stated that it stands ready to adjust all of its instruments within its mandate to ensure inflation returns to its target [3](https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/pdf/ecbu/eb202501.en.pdf#:~:text=data%2C%20the%20dynamics%20of%20underlying,all%20of%20its%20instruments%20within).
